author: Agência Brasil
title: Chuvas intensas interditam subidas para Petrópolis e Teresópolis
text: Na Serra de Teresópolis, interdição foi por precaução e fluxo de veículos foi retomado cerca de 18h. Já na de Petrópolis, já houve deslizamento (PRF/ RJ) As fortes chuvas que atingem o estado do Rio de Janeiro nesta sexta-feira (22) interromperam o trânsito de veículos da capital para as cidades serranas de Petrópolis e Teresópolis, atendidas respectivamente pelas rodovias BR-040 e BR-116. Segundo o Centro Estadual de Monitoramento e Alertas de Desastres Naturais (Cemaden), as duas cidades enfrentam risco de deslizamento. Teresópolis Devido às fortes chuvas que atingem o estado do Rio de Janeiro, a concessionária EcoRioMinas interditou totalmente nesta sexta-feira (22) o trecho da serra da estrada BR-116/RJ, que liga o Rio de Janeiro a Teresópolis, na região serrana. A via ficou interditada até cerca de 18h, quando foi retomado o tráfego de veículos À Agência Brasil, a EcoRioMinas informou, por meio de sua assessoria de imprensa, que a interdição do trecho é uma medida de precaução diante do volume de chuvas porque, quanto mais as chuvas se mantiverem ou se intensificarem, elas podem ocasionar risco de deslizamento. Petrópolis Por volta das 17h, a interdição era total no pedágio da rodovia BR-040, que liga o Rio de Janeiro a Petrópolis, na região serrana, quilômetro 102, informou a Polícia Rodoviária Federal (PRF/RJ). A concessionária Concer (Cia. de Concessão Rodoviária) recomenda aos usuários da BR-040 que não trafeguem pela rodovia, enquanto a tempestade não cessar. A Concer alerta que deve-se evitar, em especial, a serra de Petrópolis, onde já ocorreu deslizamento de terra na pista de subida, devido à chuva extrema, deixando o quilômetro 94 parcialmente interditado. Quem quiser obter informações atualizadas da rodovia pode ligar para o número gratuito 0800 2820040. Leia mais

author: Canadian Press
title: Air Transat flight attendants reject tentative deal for a second time
text:
MONTREAL — The union representing 2,100 Air Transat flight attendants has rejected a tentative agreement for the second time this year.
Some 82 per cent of the votes cast were opposed to the would-be deal, which the Canadian Union of Public Employees had reached with the airline in early January.
Compensation for hours worked before landing and after takeoff remained a key sticking point, the union said.
Flight attendants also voted overwhelmingly in favour of a new strike mandate, which will remain in effect until April 1.
The union, which rejected the first tentative agreement on Jan. 2, said the parties will return to the negotiating table quickly.
Neither party has issued a strike or lockout notice, Air Transat said.
The now-scuttled second deal included "significant improvements to the work contract as well as generous and competitive salary increases," said airline spokeswoman Andréan Gagné in an emailed statement.
"We are disappointed it was rejected for a second time. We are returning to the bargaining table and our objective remains to find a mutually satisfactory agreement as soon as possible,” said chief communications officer Julie Lamontagne.
Flight crews at the Montreal-based carrier, which is owned by tour operator Transat, first voted for a strike mandate by more than 99 per cent in November after their contract expired in the fall of 2022.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Feb. 1, 2024.
Companies in this story: (TSX:TRZ)
The Canadian Press

author: Cesar Hernandez
title: Dynamo send Carrasquilla to Pumas in record deal - ESPN
text:
Liga MX's Pumas signed Panama international Adalberto Carrasquilla for an undisclosed club-record transfer fee for Houston Dynamo FC, the MLS side announced on Thursday.
According to ESPN MX, Carrasquilla signed a multi-year deal with Pumas.
"We are proud of Coco's development into one of the most important players in MLS and Concacaf," said Dynamo president Pat Onstad in a press release. "As an organization, we are committed to developing players and helping them take the next step in their careers, and we respect Coco's desire for a new challenge in a different league.
"We wish him the best on his next step and thank him for his dedication and contributions to the Dynamo and the city of Houston."
First arriving in Houston in August of 2021, Carrasquilla made a name for himself as a well-rounded midfielder that helped the Dynamo clinch a 2023 U.S. Open Cup title and run to MLS' Western Conference final in the same season.
The 2023-24 Concacaf Men's Player of the Year scored 11 times across 116 league and cup appearances for Houston.
With Pumas, he'll seek to revive the Mexico City giants that have yet to win a league title since 2011. Carrasquilla will also be tasked with filling the playmaking boots of winger César "Chino" Huerta, who was recently traded to Belgium's Anderlecht this winter.
In Carrasquilla's final game with Houston, he was sent off in the 66th minute in game one of the Dynamo's MLS playoff series with Seattle Sounders FC. Seattle went on to win the first two games via shootout to eliminate Houston from the playoffs.

author: doaasalah
title: Brite Harvest
text:
About
At Berry Harvest, we’re all about bringing you delicious and nutritious acai bowls that support both your health and the environment. Our acai berries are carefully sourced from local farmers in Brazil, right from the heart of the Amazon. By partnering directly with these farmers, we ensure that every berry in your bowl is not only packed with natural goodness but is also sustainably harvested, supporting local communities along the way.
As part of Brite Harvest, a company dedicated to quality and sustainability, we take pride in managing the entire process—from sourcing the berries to creating our blends. Our acai is harvested fresh from Amazonian acai palm trees, preserving their authentic flavor and rich nutrients. Whether you’re enjoying one of our bowls on the go or relaxing at home, you can feel good knowing that every bite is rooted in mindful sourcing and community support.
Solution
Our packaging and branding are designed to reflect the vibrant and natural essence of Berry Harvest. We’ve created a logo that draws inspiration from the shape of a berry, with the letter “B” at its heart. This symbol is simple yet meaningful, representing both the freshness of our ingredients and our connection to nature.
We’ve used a colorful theme across our packaging to capture the energy and variety of flavors that come from our Brazilian-sourced acai. The look is bright and inviting, giving you a sense of the fun and healthy experience that comes with each bowl. Whether it’s on the shelf or in your hands, our packaging stands out with its playful yet down-to-earth design, reflecting what Berry Harvest is all about—fresh, wholesome, and real.
Results
The result is a brand that feels fresh, approachable, and true to its roots. Our vibrant packaging, paired with the berry-inspired “B” logo, makes Berry Harvest stand out while staying grounded in what matters most: delivering wholesome, delicious acai bowls. The design reflects the natural, colorful ingredients inside, making it easy for people to connect with the product.
Ultimately, our branding and packaging come together to create an inviting experience that reflects the quality and care behind each bowl, giving customers something they can enjoy and feel good about.

author: Ada Cotugno
title: L'abbraccio di Spalletti a Nosotti dopo il grave lutto: il gesto commovente prima di Croazia-Italia
text: L’abbraccio di Spalletti a Nosotti dopo il grave lutto: il gesto commovente prima di Croazia-Italia Ada Cotugno Un gesto inaspettato ma che viene dal cuore, per mostrare vicinanza in un momento delicato e tendere una mano a chi ne ha bisogno: alla viglia di Croazia-Italia Luciano Spalletti ha lasciato per un attimo le vesti di commissario tecnico della Nazionale per avvicinarsi a Marco Nosotti e sciogliersi in un lungo abbraccio. Pochi giorni fa il giornalista di SkySport ha perso la moglie Silvia in seguito a una lunga malattia, spezzando così un amore che durava da oltre 30 anni. Sono stati momenti molto duri per lui che oggi è tornato in Germania al seguito degli Azzurri ed è stato accolto dalle braccia dell'allenatore che ha voluto dedicargli un tenero pensiero. L'abbraccio di Spalletti a Nosotti Domani sera l'Italia scenderà in campo contro la Croazia per la partita decisiva di questi Europei 2024 che potrebbe sancire il passaggio agli ottavi di finale. Alla vigilia, come succede in questi casi, la squadra si è recata a Lipsia per il classico walk around dello stadio che ha coinvolto anche Spalletti. Mentre girava per il prato il tecnico toscano ha notato a bordocampo Nosotti, ritornato in Germania dopo la sua triste perdita per riprendere il lavoro a seguito della Nazionale. Il commissario tecnico si è avvicinato a lui e si è lasciato a un lungo abbraccio che vale più di ogni altra cosa, un gesto sincero per dimostrare ciò che è davvero importante. L'ex allenatore del Napoli gli ha sussurrato qualche parola all'orecchio mentre il giornalista ha ricambiato dandogli qualche pacca sulla palla in segno d'affetto. L'abbraccio è durato qualche secondo e poi ognuno ha ripreso la sua strada, vestendo i ruoli per i quali sono agli Europei: per un istante Spalletti ha abbattuto la barriera che li divide per unirsi a lui, dimenticandosi di ogni cosa in un momento così delicato.

author: Melissa Lizotte
title: Aroostook town cancels annual meeting over illegal warrants
text: WOODLAND, Maine — Fifty-six Woodland residents showed up to vote on their town and school budgets Wednesday evening only to see the meeting get canceled. After electing a moderator, Select Board Chairperson Matt Cole adjourned the meeting due to an error on the printed copies of the budget warrant that resident Rosemary Monahan alerted the board to on Tuesday. According to Maine statute, a town cannot hold its annual meeting if the Select Board does not sign the official copy of the budget warrant and/or if the town clerk does not sign attesting that the copy is genuine, Monahan said. Since town officials had already printed the warrants, they needed to call the meeting to order, elect a moderator and then make a motion to adjourn, said Select Board member Kathy Ouellette. Ouellette said that after board members heard Monahan’s concerns, they consulted with attorneys at Maine Municipal Association, who confirmed the state statute’s law. Cole adjourned the meeting around 20 minutes into the meeting, after those in attendance had elected Woodland resident Lorraine Chamberlain as their moderator. The annual town meeting will now be held Thursday, June 20, at 6 p.m. at Woodland Consolidated School’s gymnasium, or at the town garage if the school is unavailable.

author: VNExplorer
title: Tips to keep cool during lingering heatwave as BOM issues severe storm warnings for Qld, NSW
text:
Locals try to cool off in outback town Boulia, as the mercury heads towards 45C. (Supplied: Zacahary Hart)
Scorching temperatures are hitting communities across the east coast of Australia with even hotter conditions and severe storms expected later on Friday and over the weekend.
Much of northern Australia is sweltering through heatwave conditions set to peak in some areas on Saturday and endure into the new year.
On Queensland’s coast, many residents will ring in 2024 displaced from ruined homes amid a colossal clean-up in the aftermath of this week’s severe storms in the south-east and ex-tropical cyclone Jasper.
Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) data showed many towns across Queensland sweltering through near-40-degree Celsius heat at 10am on Friday, with hotter temperatures expected over the weekend for some communities.
On the coast, Brisbane had reached 37.5C at 1:00pm on Friday while the Gold Coast was expecting to hit 33C, but a seabreeze kept temperatures closer to 30C.
Further inland, the mercury rose, with Emerald reaching 36.9C at 1.54pm and Roma topping out at 39.2C at 1.38pm..
In the outback, temperatures were tipped to skyrocket to 47C in Birdsville.
Longreach will be in record-breaking territory if it reaches more than 47C as expected over the weekend —beating the previous maximum temperature of 47.3 from January, 1990.
“This weekend, a number of locations will reach above 40C, and into the mid-to-high 40s,” said the BOM’s Claire Yeo.
West and central Queensland as well as the Top End were set to suffer some of the most extreme heat with Marble Bar in Western Australia expecting the hottest temperature in the country — 48C on Saturday, the Bureau said.
More severe storms predicted BOM has issued severe storm warnings for parts of Queensland and northern New South Wales across the weekend, with the potential for destructive winds, giant hail and flash flooding.
Severe thunderstorms may impact locations from Port Macquarie up to Rockhampton in Central Queensland and inland to Emerald and Roma on Saturday.
The focus will be through south east Queensland, including Brisbane and the Gold Coast.
People living in these regions or travelling through these areas are urged to pay close attention to forecasts and radar images.
On Sunday, the risk of severe thunderstorms eases in New South Wales but will continue in Queensland with intense rainfall predicted.
Health warnings for the vulnerable Meanwhile, Queensland Ambulance Service officer Brad Hardy said hospitals around the state were bracing for an uptick in heat-related illnesses.
He urged those susceptible to the heat — the elderly, children and pregnant women — to be aware of signs of heat stress.
“As soon as you start sweating you’re losing fluids and can rapidly become dehydrated if you’re in these really hot temperatures,” Superintendent Hardy said.
“You can become restless, flushed in the skin to the point where you stop sweating.
“That’s extremely dangerous and can be fatal … your organs can start to shut down to keep your brain working and that damage can be immense and irreversible.”
For more tips on how to stay safe in a heatwave visit the ABC Emergency website here.
Residents get creative to keep cool Tried and tested methods like keeping ice blocks handy, hauling out the paddle pool, buckets of water and cool drinks were the go-to for residents trying to stay cool.
Tradesmen in the outback town of Cloncurry used their water trucks to spray neighbours cooling off in backyards and the Gold Coast council offered free entry to the local pools.
Fire stations at Mount Tamborine opened their doors to people who needed an air-conditioned place to cool down.
In Birdsville, ranger Don Rowlands said locals had a few tricks for dealing with the hottest time of the year.
“You start your day early and by 10am, everyone retires to the lounge room and puts on a good movie in the air-conditioning,” he said.
“The kids run down to the river early in the morning and come home late at night … they’re just swimming all day.”
Nicole Liu, in the outback town of Mount Isa, where temperatures were set to reach 45C over the weekend, said she had to bring her kids to the pool early to beat the stifling heat.
“You have to come early otherwise you just can’t enjoy it. We’re here at 9.30am and it already feels like you’re standing in an oven,” she said.
As an outback local, Ms Liu said residents expected temperatures to be high this time of year, but that the heat “still hits you pretty hard”.
“We hang around the pool and keep ice blocks handy, crank the aircon…I’m not looking forward to my electricity bill,” she said.
Iced coffees were in hot demand at Nambour cafe Small Change Espresso this morning, with the town expected to reach 37C.
Worker Alex Atkins said he had noticed fewer customers opting to dine in.
“A lot more iced coffees than usual,” he said.
“Because of the heat people are getting takeaways because it’s too hot to sit in here.”
He said the store had several large fans running but they were doing little to bring the temperature down.
“We’ve stocked our fridges with cold water, people are asking for water as soon as they walk in,” he said.
“It was already hot as soon as we got here and we’ve got fans to work with.”
Helping animals beat the heat Grazier Josie Angus from the central Queensland community of Clermont was helping her cattle get through 39C temperatures.
She said her stock was northern bred and used to high temperatures, but it was still difficult to keep them cool.
“It’s always an extra challenge,” Ms Angus said.
“All of our cattle are on heat-load rations and we cool down their ration a bit just to make sure that they’re going to cope with it.”
The RSPCA recommends multiple sources of water in shady spots for pets.
Cooling matts, paddle pools and frozen treats are another way to help your furry friend beat the heat.
“Never leave your dog tied up in the yard or in a hot car during a heatwave,” the RSPCA website warns.
Rain on the way but heat to endure While the hottest day for the northern half of Australia will be Saturday, temperatures will not drop by much over the coming week, the BOM says.
Storms and rain were predicted for parts of the central west and east coast over the weekend while a chance of rain was forecast for western and north-west Queensland mid-to-late next week.
While the rain would bring some reprieve, it would not do much to ease the heat, Ms Yeo said.
“Central and western Queensland maximum temperatures unfortunately do not fall below 40 degrees for the remainder of the week.”
Superintendent Hardy urged all those in heat-affected areas to take it easy.
“Temperatures are not just a few degrees above average, they’re up to many degrees above average,” he said.
“Stay cool and take the risk of heat stress very seriously.”
